segments.key_quote: when Krishna was leaving the palace of Hastinapura there were brahmanas who were glorifying Krishna by chanting Vedic hymns and offering benediction to Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 19th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on the apparent contradiction of offering benedictions to Krishna, who is the Absolute.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing the 19th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: Ashu yantashisha satyah tatra tatra dvijeritah na anuroopa anuroopascha nirgunasya gunatmanah. The meaning of this verse is: It was being heard here and there that the benedictions being paid to Krishna were neither befitting nor unbefitting because they were all for the absolute who was now playing the part of a human being. A very important observation being made is that when Krishna was leaving the palace of Hastinapura, there were brahmanas who were glorifying Krishna by chanting Vedic hymns and offering benediction to Krishna. Now, it is described in this verse that the benedictions that were being offered to Krishna were neither befitting nor unbefitting, so something like a contradiction, it appears as a contradictory statement here.

segments.key_quote: Krishna was playing the part of a human being though he is not a human being. He is the Supreme Lord always under all circumstances but he is playing the part of a human being.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's explanation of the verse, highlighting that Krishna was playing the role of a human being as a guest of Yudhishthira, making the benedictions fitting in that context.
segments.transcript: So Prabhupada explains this in the purport very nicely. Why is it being said it was neither befitting nor unbefitting? So Srila Prabhupada says in the purport: At places there were sounds of Vedic benediction at the personality of God is Shri Krishna. The benedictions were fitting in the sense that the Lord was playing the part of a human being as if a cousin of Maharaj Yudhishthira. Krishna appeared as the son of Vasudeva who was the brother of Kuntidevi and Kuntidevi's son was Yudhishthira. So Yudhishthira and Krishna were cousins in terms of relationship, but here it is said because Krishna was playing the part of a human being, though he is not a human being. He is the Supreme Lord always under all circumstances, but he is playing the part of a human being. Therefore, the benedictions were fitting because Yudhishthira is the elder brother of Krishna. So the elder brother arranges to offer benedictions by the qualified brahmanas and the benediction it is accepted which will be offered through chanting of various hymns to the important guest. Krishna has come to the Hastinapura palace as the guest of Yudhishthira.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is described as nirguna, nirguna means absolute, without any material qualities. So he is not a human being, he has no material relationship with anybody.
segments.summary: The speaker explains why the benedictions were also unbefitting, because Krishna is absolute (nirguna) and doesn't need material benefits, and that He creates the material world for our sake.
segments.transcript: So in that sense, there it is befitting because Krishna was playing the part of a human being, but they were unbefitting because the Lord is absolute, material qualities, material relativities. Now Krishna is described as nirguna, nirguna means absolute, without any material qualities. So he is not a human being, he has no material relationship with anybody. So therefore this benediction is not suited for Krishna, it is only for people of this world who have some kind of material relationships and they want some benedictions because they may utilize those benedictions for their material benefit. Lacking those material benefits, they may desire some benedictions which will help them to get some material benefits. But Krishna is not in need of any material benefit. Krishna has nothing to do with this entire material creation as far as his activities are concerned or his existence is concerned. Then why does he create? He creates for our sake.

segments.key_quote: And we are foolish to desire material enjoyment while we are entitled to sublime spiritual pleasure in his association.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how humans foolishly seek material happiness instead of spiritual bliss in connection with Krishna, who creates the material world because we insist on trying to enjoy it.
segments.transcript: Why does he create? And we are foolish to desire material enjoyment while we are entitled to sublime spiritual pleasure in his association. So foolishly we have turned away from Krishna, foolishly we seek happiness in material pursuits and Krishna because we are his part and parcel, we are his own children. So because we insist, we are adamant, Krishna creates this material world and places us in this material atmosphere, so we can try to enjoy it materially and try to be happy in this way. But intelligent people realize we can never be happy in this material world by pursuit of material pleasures. We can never be happy. We can never be happy, so intelligent persons try to find out the real source of happiness and that is available only in connection with Krishna, unlimited spiritual bliss. Krishna is a reservoir of that and in our relationship with Krishna, spiritual relationship, not material relationship, we can have
